So he focused all his time and energy on earning money, and neglected other things that could make him grow as a well-rounded person?
My dad died when I was young and I struggled ever since.   But if I didn't fall to that poverty, I wouldn't be who I am now.   And I proud of myself being who I am, what I achieved so far.
Thatâ€™s how I feel. No matter what we get for the house itâ€™s an amazing gift from them. The goofy sentimental things are what I value.

my dad raised me to be independent too,  he didn't buy me cars, fancy phone and any other fancy stuff.   but he provided me with all basic needs so I can focus on learning, he paid for all my education till college, buy me phone and paid the bill, a computer, allowance, motorcycle for everyday transport, by all means, none of it are fancy, just a basic needs.  now i'm in mid 20, just left home last month, with my dream job and pursuing career in it, without parents financial support, even trying to ease their burden with paying for my brother college fees.  while it's important to make your kid independent, providing basic needs for them to be independent is also parents responsibility.  if you can't provide for them, don't make kids. kids are expensive.

So miss out on enjoying youth for the sakes of financial capital? Nonsense. I never asked for anything from my parents, and I've worked hard to get into a great position where I live very comfortably. However, when I have kids, I will allow them to enjoy my wealth AND teach them the value of effort and hard work. These are mutually exclusive. You can have one without the other, and you can have both.  It's all about raising children with an understanding and an appreciation of the value of money. You can still do this, even when rewarding them as such in this comic.

But even if you dad really gave you house and car, it doesn't mean that you won't work hard to acheive financial independence. So, I only agree to this story to a certain extent. I believe parents' gifts don't really affect own hard work, it depends on mentality.
Inspiring. But secretly still wishing I am a trust fund baby so I can retire and be a nomad around the world.
I read Rich Dad Poor Dad recently, and as you said, right mindset is the most important thing

My dad always promise me he wants to inherit me wealth he doesn't have. Maybe some of my siblings keep his words and keep waiting for what my dad has promised us. But I don't. I work hard myself and never depending on him, if he would give me any someday I just won't accept it. Coz in his age he is not suppose to work hard just so he can inherit something for us, his children. It is time for him to have some rest and let the children repay whatever he has given us...

If you work in the arts and media, then it's literally true for the kiddos. They will inherit nothing since we fellas working in media are poor so really, we will have nothing for them to inherit. Actually, they will be lucky if we are not taking money from them instead...

I think parents could have used another way of saying be financially independent instead of using harsh words that make the child bitter, lost all the time of building meaningful friendship, relationships, the mind became so obsessed with money, wasted so many years of being sad and traumatized by such harsh words is not worth it. The word used is just not wise in my opinion.

On another note: In Asia, most parents not only telling their children that the kids would inherit nothing, but the children would also need to take care of their parents when the parents are old. They raise you up, so you are forever indebted to them. So you are lucky if you are set free after you are independent, unlike some people who have to financially support their parents.
